abstract.text: W bosons are produced at LHC from a forward-backward symmetric initial state.
Their decay to a charged lepton and a neutrino has a strong spin analysing power.
The combination of these effects results in characteristic distributions of the pseudorapidity of the leptons decaying from W + and W − of different helicity.
This observation may open the possibility to measure precisely the W + and W − rapidity distributions for the two transverse polarisation states of W bosons produced at small transverse momentum.

Conclusions 6
At hadron colliders the W + and W − bosons are copiously produced, primarily created by the interaction of a quark with an anti-quark.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: Events with a W decaying into lepton and neutrino (W → ν) can be easily triggered and selected with high purity.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: However, the neutrino escaping detection prevents the direct measurement of the W differential production cross sections.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: Particularly, the rapidity and polarisation distributions of the W must be inferred by the proton Parton Distribution Functions (PDFs).
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: In turn, the PDFs have been constrained by measuring asymmetries in events where a W boson is produced.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: The relative rate of W + and W − produced at the Tevatron as a function of their rapidity has been measured [1,2] using a method proposed in [3].
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: This observable is sensitive to the ratio of the u quark and d quark PDFs.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: Another observable constraining the PDFs is the lepton charge asymmetry, the relative rate of the charged leptons from W decays, as a function of the lepton pseudorapidity.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: It has been measured at the Tevatron and LHC [10][11][12][13][14][15][16].
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: All these measurements have been used to constrain the PDFs, which are then used to compute the rapidity and polarisation distributions of the W .
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: A possible extension of the method of reference [3] to LHC has been studied in [17] concluding that in proton proton collisions this technique is less useful for placing constraints on the PDFs than a measurement of the lepton charge asymmetry.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: The accuracy of the rapidity and polarisation distribution of the W is one of the limiting factors in the precise measurement of the W mass at hadron colliders [18].
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: The so called PDFs uncertainty in the W mass determination, stemming from the uncertainty in the PDFs used to compute the rapidity and polarisation distributions, amounts to about 10 MeV in the most recent measurements [19][20][21].
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: This paper presents some observations on the characteristics of the W production at LHC and subsequent decay, which may allow for a precise direct measurement of the rapidity and polarisation distributions of the W + and W − .
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: The LHC experiments have already collected huge samples O(10 9 ) of W bosons where the W decays into a neutrino and a lepton 1 with large enough transverse momentum to trigger the data acquisition.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: The W bosons are characterised in the reference frame of the experiment by their rapidity y, transverse momentum p W t and polarisation.
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: The leptons from their decay are characterised by their transverse momentum p t and pseudorapidity
body_text.section: Conclusions 6

body_text.text: η, where η = − ln tan θ 2 and θ is the polar angle measured from the z axis, coincident with the common directions of the two proton beams.
The pseudorapidity of the lepton in the W reference frame is η 0 .
The leptons from W decays have typically p t larger than 25 GeV -because of the trigger acceptance -and smaller than 50 GeV because most of the W bosons are produced at low transverse momentum.
The most probable value of p W t is about 5 GeV.
For transverse momenta much smaller than the W mass M W , the W has essentially only transverse polarisation and two helicity states.
This approximation will be used in the discussion presented in this paper.

body_text.text: Uncertainty on W rapidity and helicity distributions
We investigate now if this new observation can be used to measure the W rapidity and helicity distributions with a smaller uncertainty with respect to the prediction by the PDFs.
body_text.section: Uncertainty on W rapidity and helicity distributions

body_text.text: We present a very simple analysis using W + events simulated with PYTHIA 8.2 and NNPDF3.1 and performing a template fit of the p t vs. η distribution of the positive leptons measured in the acceptance 25 < p t < 50 GeV and |η| < 2.5.
body_text.section: Uncertainty on W rapidity and helicity distributions

body_text.text: Templates of 50 bins in η and 25 bins in p t are built for W + produced in 17 bins of rapidity for the two helicity states in the range −3.5 < y < 3.

body_text.text: We have investigated the effect of the uncertainty in the lepton trigger and identification efficiency as function of η , the uncertainty on the assumed values of the W mass and the uncertainty on the shape of the p W t spectrum.

body_text.text: The first two effects induce changes on the shape that are smaller than the statistical uncertainty for a 1% random efficiency shift uncorrelated in each η bin or for a shift of the W mass of 50 MeV.

body_text.text: Conclusions
The W symmetric production at LHC and its asymmetric decay for a fixed helicity result in characteristic distributions of the p t vs. η of the charged leptons stemming from the W decay.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: These distributions may be used for a direct measurement of the W + and W − JHEP12(2017)130 rapidity for the two helicity states of W bosons produced at small transverse momentum.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: This measurement has a statistical uncertainty much smaller than the PDFs prediction.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The final systematic accuracy of the measurement can only be assessed with a full analysis of the data already collected by the LHC experiments.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: At the level of the simple analysis shown in this paper, the proposed method has the potentiality of reducing the uncertainty on the W rapidity and helicity distribution.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: An improved determination of the rapidity and helicity distributions of the W + and W − will result in a smaller systematic uncertainty in the measurement of W mass at LHC.
body_text.section: Conclusions
